content.raw: I'm confused as to what should go into the `ign-transport4` branch then :confused: It was my understanding that we only create a major release branch when we're ready to release, and from then on, the new default branch will receive breaking changes that will be released on the next major.
content.html: I'm confused as to what should go into the ign-transport4 branch then It was my understanding that we only create a major release branch when we're ready to release, and from then on, the new default branch will receive breaking changes that will be released on the next major.

content.raw:
I think we make a major release branch when we're ready to start the packaging process, which includes making prereleases. Before an official release, the default branch and release branch should be interchangeable; there can't be "breaking changes" if there isn't anything to break yet. After the release, breaking changes to go default.

That's my understanding at least
content.html:
I think we make a major release branch when we're ready to start the packaging process, which includes making prereleases. Before an official release, the default branch and release branch should be interchangeable; there can't be "breaking changes" if there isn't anything to break yet. After the release, breaking changes to go default.

That's my understanding at least

content.raw: I think we bumped to 4 on the `ign-transport4` branch and had never merged from 4 -> default, so that's why it was still 3
content.html: I think we bumped to 4 on the ign-transport4 branch and had never merged from 4 -> default, so that's why it was still 3

content.raw: You could bump default to 5, historically we have only bumped the default version number when it became necessary to distinguish between versions. There is no reason *not* to bump the version though, and it would be more clear that default is working toward a new major version.
content.html: You could bump default to 5, historically we have only bumped the default version number when it became necessary to distinguish between versions. There is no reason not to bump the version though, and it would be more clear that default is working toward a new major version.

content.raw: unless there were new features we specifically don't want in version 4, I would advocate waiting until there's an official release before bumping the default branch version, mainly because sometimes pull requests get merged to default when they could still go to the unreleased branch
content.html: unless there were new features we specifically don't want in version 4, I would advocate waiting until there's an official release before bumping the default branch version, mainly because sometimes pull requests get merged to default when they could still go to the unreleased branch

content.raw:
We would have to backport those changes through a new PR. The review process should avoid merging a future version number into a released version. 

Eventually, we have to bump the number on default before the next release to avoid overwriting a release version with default.
content.html:
We would have to backport those changes through a new PR. The review process should avoid merging a future version number into a released version.

Eventually, we have to bump the number on default before the next release to avoid overwriting a release version with default.

content.raw: Having the version number be the same on the default branch and the release branch wouldn't help much with that if you forget to merge default into the release branch before the release.
content.html: Having the version number be the same on the default branch and the release branch wouldn't help much with that if you forget to merge default into the release branch before the release.

content.raw:
Attempt of summarizing the talk with @scpeters and @caguero IRL:

* We should be better communicating both internally and externally:
    * When a (pre-)release branch has been created off of default
    * Until when that will be considered a pre-release
    * When the release has been officially made
* Pre-release branches do not necessarily mean they are in code freeze and there may be breaking changes
* Whoever is making the pre-releases should make sure there aren't any changes on default which should be ported to the pre-release branch before pulling the trigger
* Once an official release has been made (and clearly communicated to the whole community!) we should consider making it a policy to always bump the default branch's version
    * This requires creating new homebrew formulas
content.html:
Attempt of summarizing the talk with @scpeters and @caguero IRL:

  • We should be better communicating both internally and externally:
    • When a (pre-)release branch has been created off of default
    • Until when that will be considered a pre-release
    • When the release has been officially made
  • Pre-release branches do not necessarily mean they are in code freeze and there may be breaking changes
  • Whoever is making the pre-releases should make sure there aren't any changes on default which should be ported to the pre-release branch before pulling the trigger
  • Once an official release has been made (and clearly communicated to the whole community!) we should consider making it a policy to always bump the default branch's version
    • This requires creating new homebrew formulas

content.raw:
Most of the communication aspect should be solved with the ignitionrobotics.org site.

Additionally, you can use 'hg tags' to see the releases, and packages.osrfoundation.org.
content.html:
Most of the communication aspect should be solved with the ignitionrobotics.org site.

Additionally, you can use 'hg tags' to see the releases, and packages.osrfoundation.org.

content.raw: Sorry for being late to the party. We have talked about this in person but I leave it on the record here. We bumped default to `4.0.0` at some point but that broke CI because we didn't have an updated Homebrew formula. That's why we reverted the version to `3.x.x`. Then, we were about to release a bunch of changes, so I created the `ign-transport4` release branch and targeted the PRs to that branch. However, not all the changes that we want for `ign-transport4` are ready, that's why it hasn't been released yet.
content.html: Sorry for being late to the party. We have talked about this in person but I leave it on the record here. We bumped default to 4.0.0 at some point but that broke CI because we didn't have an updated Homebrew formula. That's why we reverted the version to 3.x.x. Then, we were about to release a bunch of changes, so I created the ign-transport4 release branch and targeted the PRs to that branch. However, not all the changes that we want for ign-transport4 are ready, that's why it hasn't been released yet.

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/310
